input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: William Sanford "Bill" Nye (born 1955) is an American science educator and television host. Nye studied mechanical engineering at Cornell University before earning a master's degree in mechanical engineering from Cornell in 1977. He gained popularity as host of "Bill Nye the Science Guy," which aired on PBS from 1993-1998 and again in 2005-2006. Nye has also served as executive director of the Planetary Society, a space advocacy organization, since 1998. Nye is a vocal proponent of science literacy and has authored several children's books and other works of non-fiction.

input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: Bill Nye (born 1955) is an American science communicator, TV host, and mechanical engineer. He was known for hosting the children's science TV show "Bill Nye the Science Guy" from 1993-1998. He has authored books on science and hosted the Netflix show "Bill Nye Saves the World" in 2017. Nye has been an advocate for scientific literacy and has criticized those who deny the existence of climate change. He has been involved in protests against the Dakota Access Pipeline and was a member of the Advisory Board for Al Gore's 2007 book "The Climate Reality Project." He also served on the Board of Trustees of The Planetary Society from 1996 to 2022. Nye's work as an engineer earned him the nickname "Science Guy."

output: Bill Nye (born 1955) is an American science communicator, television host, and author. Nye's father was a mechanical engineer, inspiring his interest in science. He received a degree in mechanical engineering from Cornell University in 1977 and worked for Boeing before joining PBS. Nye hosted the Emmy Award-winning TV show "Bill Nye the Science Guy" from 1993-1998, using humor and music to explain science topics. input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman politician, soldier, and general who played a crucial role in the transformation of the Roman Republic into an Empire. A member of the First Triumvirate, he served as Dictator of the Roman Republic before his assassination. Born in Rome, Caesar was involved in various military campaigns across Europe, rising to prominence in the process. After becoming a consul in 59 BC, he served in the Gallic Wars before returning to Rome. As Dictator, he passed laws, rebuilt the city, and expanded the republic. During his tenure, Caesar was assassinated by a group of senators on the Ides of March in 44 BC.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general, statesman, and historian. He rose through the ranks of the Roman Republic to become dictator of Rome. His military campaigns expanded the empire's territory and influenced the development of Roman law and government. Caesar led the Senate in creating the Julian calendar. He was assassinated by conspirators, who feared his growing power. Caesar was regarded as a ruthless tyrant by some but also as a hero by others.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman general and statesman. He conquered Gaul and was elected consul in 59 BC. In 49 BC, Caesar led a coup against the Roman Republic, seizing control of Rome and declaring himself dictator for life. He defeated Pompey in the Roman Civil War and reformed the Roman Senate. His efforts to overhaul the Republic resulted in assassination in 44 BC, sparking civil war that ultimately led to Augustus's rise to power. His legacy includes the development of the Roman Empire, the introduction of the Julian calendar, and his writings on law and history.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman military leader and statesman, one of the most prominent figures of the late Roman Republic. A general during the Gallic Wars, he returned to Rome a hero, elected consul in 59 BCE. He led a military campaign in North Africa and then served as governor of Spain. In 49 BCE, he crossed the Rubicon with his army, starting the Civil War against the Senate. Caesar defeated Pompey in a series of battles and was named dictator. He then launched a military campaign in Egypt and became the sole ruler of the Roman Empire in 44 BCE, assuming the title of "Imperator". He was assassinated in a conspiracy the next year.

Caesar led a military campaign that conquered most of Gaul and founded the city of Paris. He defeated Pompey in a civil war and became the leader of the Senate. Caesar implemented political and social reforms, and expanded the empire. He was assassinated by a group of senators led by Marcus Brutus.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Gaius Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman statesman and general during the Late Roman Republic. He rose through the military ranks to become dictator of Rome in 49 BCE. Caesar also led several successful military campaigns in Italy, defeating Pompey at Pharsalus in 48 BCE. After defeating Pompey, Caesar's power threatened the Roman Republic, leading to his assassination in 44 BCE. He was one of the greatest military commanders in history, winning more battles than any other Roman. His campaigns led to the conquest of Gaul, Britain, and Egypt.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) was a Roman statesman, general, and dictator. He rose through the ranks of the Roman military to command the campaigns in Gaul, leading Rome to victory. He became the first Roman general to cross the Alps and defeat the Germanic tribes. Caesar was also known for his political reforms and writings, including the Commentaries on the Gallic Wars. He was assassinated by senators in 44 BC, an event that sparked a civil war that led to his nephew, Octavian, becoming the first Emperor of Rome.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) was a Roman general and statesman, serving as dictator and later assassinated by senators who opposed his power grab. Caesar rose through the ranks during the Roman civil wars and led Rome to victory in its long-running conflict with Gaul. He was elected consul in 59 BC and dictator in 49 BC, assuming sweeping powers over the republic. Caesar then annexed much of Gaul and made himself dictator for life in 44 BC. He was assassinated by senators at the Idus of March on the Ides of March, which subsequently became the name of a holiday in the Julian calendar.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Gaius Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general and statesman who played a key role in the transition from the Roman Republic to the Roman Empire. He became a dictator for life in 48 BCE, and then launched a series of conquests in Europe and North Africa. He was murdered by senators who feared his growing power. Caesar was an effective military leader, but his authoritarian style led to his downfall. His legacy lives on in modern politics and literature, and he is regarded as one of the greatest figures in history.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BCE-44 BCE) was a Roman military and political leader. After rising through the ranks, he was elected consul and campaigned against the Achaemenid Empire. During the civil war that followed, he defeated Pompey and became sole consul. He invaded Britain in 55 BCE, before returning to Rome to quell a civil war and gain power. As a dictator, he reformed the Roman Senate and strengthened the military. After his assassination in 44 BCE, his heir, Octavian, led the Roman Republic.

input: Write a short biography of Howard Zinn.
output: Howard Zinn (1922-2010) was an American historian, activist, and writer who authored influential works including "A People's History of the United States." Zinn attended Spelman College and later the University of Chicago, where he met fellow history professor Staughton Lynd. The two later married and co-founded the Radical History Project, which chronicled progressive social movements. After teaching at Spelman, Boston University, and the City College of New York, Zinn wrote "A People's History" (1980), which popularized left-wing perspectives on U.S. history. Zinn's opposition to the Vietnam War and support for civil rights and women's rights caused controversy and led to him being investigated by the FBI.

input: Write a short biography of Howard Zinn.
output: Howard Zinn (1922-2010) was a historian and activist who wrote numerous books, including "A People's History of the United States." He was a socialist and a pacifist who advocated for civil rights and anti-war movements. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he enlisted in the Air Force during World War II and became a bombardier. After the war, Zinn earned a Ph.D. from Columbia University. He taught at Spelman College in Atlanta for over 20 years and gained national prominence with his 1980 book, "A People's History of the United States." Zinn critiqued traditional history for emphasizing the perspective of the wealthy and powerful and for excluding women, people of color, and the working class. His writing challenged readers to see history from a different perspective and to confront injustice.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones are a British rock band formed in London in 1962. Originally called the Rollin' Stones, they were one of the first bands to pioneer the gritty, raw sound of blues rock that would come to define the 1960s counterculture. The group's frontman, Mick Jagger, has been hailed as one of the greatest rock singers of all time. The Rolling Stones have released numerous chart-topping albums, including Beggars Banquet (1968), Exile on Main St. (1972), Some Girls (1978), Tattoo You (1981), and A Bigger Bang (2005). They have sold over 200 million records worldwide and have been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame twice.

The Stones were formed in London by Brian Jones, Mick Jagger, and Keith Richards. The band took inspiration from American blues and rhythm and blues, which they performed in a style known as British blues. In the mid-1960s, they developed a gritty, hard-rocking sound that influenced generations of musicians. After Jones left the band, The Stones continued to release music and tour into the 21st century. The band is credited with influencing pop culture and fashion, and its 1969 album, "Let It Bleed," reached No. 1 in the United States and the United Kingdom.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is an English primatologist known for her study of chimpanzees in Africa. Goodall worked as a secretary before leaving for Tanzania in 1960, where she stayed for several years. In 1977, she founded the Jane Goodall Institute to support conservation and community-focused projects. Goodall's work has inspired activism for wildlife and environmental protection. She was made a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire (DBE) in 2004.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (1934-present) is a British primatologist who studied chimpanzees in Tanzania's Gombe Stream National Park for 45 years. She first observed chimps in 1960 as a student volunteer and continued her research for over five decades. Goodall popularized the term "cultural transmission," which refers to the way chimpanzees pass on knowledge from one generation to the next. Goodall founded the Jane Goodall Institute in 1977 to protect chimpanzees and their habitats. She has been a UN Messenger of Peace since 2002.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist and conservationist known for her study of chimpanzees in Gombe National Park. She began her field research in 1960 and eventually moved to Tanzania permanently. In 1977, she founded the Jane Goodall Institute to promote conservation and research, now with offices in 19 countries. The institute also operates Roots & Shoots, a program for young people. Goodall has published more than 40 books, received many honors, and founded the United Nations Environment Programme's Ethics and Economics Commission.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist and anthropologist. She was the first to study chimpanzees in their natural habitat, observing their social structures and behaviors. Goodall worked at Gombe National Park in Tanzania, where she was the first to record chimpanzees making and using tools, hunting food, and displaying emotions. She also observed their mother-child bonds and sexual relations. Her groundbreaking research influenced modern primatology and conservation efforts. Goodall has received numerous awards and honors and continues to study and advocate for chimpanzees and conservation efforts.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist, ethologist, and UN Messenger of Peace. She is best known for her work studying wild chimpanzees in Tanzania, documenting their behavior and cultural traditions. Goodall began her research at age 26, after her father loaned her money to buy a plane ticket to Africa. Her work led to the creation of the Jane Goodall Institute, which protects primates and teaches people about their needs. Goodall has received numerous honors and awards for her work. She is the author of many books on primates and environmental issues.

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (1934-present) is an English primatologist known for her groundbreaking studies of chimpanzees in Africa. Goodall was born in London and raised in Bournemouth. She began her studies with chimpanzees in 1957. Her work led to a lifelong passion for primate conservation. Goodall's studies challenged many of the prevailing theories about primate behavior, highlighting their abilities to make and use tools and hunt for meat. Her research has been critical for understanding chimpanzees' social and ecological roles. She also founded the Jane Goodall Institute, which promotes conservation and research.

input: Write a short biography of Melinda French Gates.
output: Melinda French Gates (born 1964) is an American businesswoman, philanthropist, and former Microsoft employee. She and Bill Gates founded the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which invests in health, education, and technology. As a child, French worked as a paralegal, and later attended Duke University, where she met Gates. After marrying Gates, French founded Pivotal Software, a company that made internet software. She served on the board of directors for Starbucks and Microsoft. French has authored books about gender equality and health disparities, and has been recognized for her work in philanthropy and business.

output: Melinda French Gates (born 1964) is an American businesswoman and philanthropist. She co-founded and co-chairs the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which aims to reduce poverty and improve health worldwide. She previously worked at Microsoft as Bill Gates's wife, advising him on philanthropy. She stepped down as CEO of the foundation in 2021 to focus on her advocacy and writing work. French Gates has advocated for gender equality and has helped fund initiatives to promote gender equity and empower women. She has also written about her own experiences with sexual abuse and has become an advocate for survivors of sexual abuse and assault.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69 BC - 30 BC) was an Egyptian queen and the last ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty. She rose to power in 51 BC at the age of 18 and became the lover of Julius Caesar. She later became the wife of Mark Antony, a Roman general and politician. The couple ruled jointly, but their relationship ended when Octavian, Caesar's nephew and heir, forced them to commit suicide. Cleopatra was renowned for her beauty, charm, and political savvy, and her legacy has endured in popular culture for centuries.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69 BC-30 BC) was an ancient Egyptian queen, the last ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom. She gained power after her father's death, ruling jointly with her brothers, then alone. She forged an alliance with Rome by marrying Julius Caesar and then Mark Antony. After Antony's death, she committed suicide by snakebite, which was immortalized in Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar." Cleopatra was a fluent speaker of Koine Greek and an educated leader with wide-ranging interests. Though often portrayed as a sensual seductress, she is also recognized as a formidable strategist and diplomat.

He began his career as a teenager on the soap opera Family Affairs before starring in British films like Daddy's Little Girls (2007). In the US, Elba became known for his role as Stringer Bell on The Wire (2002-2004). He has acted in numerous films, including Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom (2013) and Luther (2010-2019), and has directed films and documentaries. input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is an American-Israeli psychologist and Nobel Prize winner. Kahneman was raised in Tel Aviv and served in the Israeli army during the Six-Day War. He studied at the University of Jerusalem and was influenced by the psychologists Amos Tversky and Paul Slovic. Kahneman joined the faculty at the University of British Columbia in 1964, where he specialized in behavioral economics. He moved to the United States in 1973 and became a professor at Princeton University. Kahneman coined the term "prospect theory" to describe people's irrational choices, and his work has been credited with helping to bring behavioral economics into the mainstream. He won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 2002.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is an Israeli psychologist and professor emeritus at Princeton University. He was born in Budapest, Hungary. During World War II, he and his family moved to France, where they were imprisoned by the Germans. They were liberated by American forces and immigrated to Israel. Their work has had a significant impact on the field of psychology and has been applied to fields such as economics and medicine.

input: Write a short biography of Mark Twain.
output: Samuel Langhorne Clemens (1835-1910), known as Mark Twain, was an American writer and humorist. He is best known for his novels The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, considered classics of American literature. Twain worked as a steamboat pilot before the Civil War. During the conflict, he served as a Confederate soldier and prisoner of war. He began his writing career in 1865, publishing the satirical pamphlet "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County" and the novel The Gilded Age. Afterwards, Twain became a well-known figure in the literary community, writing humor, travelogues, and fiction. He died in 1910 from complications of a stroke.

output: Samuel Langhorne Clemens (1835-1910), better known by his pen name Mark Twain, was an American author, humorist, and lecturer. He later relocated to San Francisco and established a career as a travel writer. His first book, "The Innocents Abroad," was published in 1869. In addition to his literary work, Twain also spoke out against slavery and injustice. He died on April 21, 1910, at the age of 74.

input: Write a short biography of Mark Twain.
output: Samuel Clemens (1835-1910), better known as Mark Twain, was an American author and humorist. Twain was born in Florida, Missouri, and worked as a printer and journalist before turning to writing. His first novel, The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876), was followed by The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1885), both set in his boyhood home of Hannibal, Missouri. Twain wrote comic and satirical works like A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1889) and was a vocal critic of slavery. His later years were marred by bankruptcy, a bitter divorce, and a series of scandals.

input: Write a short biography of Mark Twain.
output: Mark Twain (1835-1910) was an American author and humorist. He was best known for his novel "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" (1884), which satirizes racism and slavery in the South. Twain also wrote satirical stories, essays, and letters that criticized corrupt politicians and organized religion. His writings were praised for their humor, wit, and humanism. Twain was born Samuel Clemens in Missouri, and his father died when he was 12. Twain started working as a printer, apprenticing under his older brother Orion, who became his literary agent. Twain moved to New York City to work as a newspaper reporter in 1851 and traveled to the Mississippi River in 1861 to cover the Civil War. He settled in Hartford, Connecticut, in 1871, where he wrote and lectured. Twain became a leading literary figure in the U.S., and his writings have had a lasting impact on American culture.

output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was an African American civil rights activist and seamstress from Montgomery, Alabama. She is remembered as an icon of the civil rights movement and a symbol of nonviolent resistance to racial inequality.

input: Write a short biography of Audre Lorde.
output: Audre Lorde (1934-1992) was a writer, activist, and civil rights icon. Born in New York City, Lorde grew up in Harlem and worked as a librarian. She became active in the civil rights movement, writing for The Black Panther and publishing her first book, "Cables to Rage," in 1970. Her 1982 book "The Cancer Journals" brought her fame as a poet and writer. Lorde advocated for feminist, gay, and African American rights, organizing protests and raising awareness of racism and discrimination. She was diagnosed with breast cancer in 1978 and died of the disease in 1992.

input: Write a short biography of Neil Armstrong.
output: Neil Armstrong (1930-2012) was an American astronaut and aeronautical engineer. He served as a naval aviator during the Korean War and joined the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA), later NASA, in 1955. He piloted Gemini 8 and Apollo 11, becoming the first person to walk on the Moon on July 20, 1969. His historic achievement has been immortalized in film and books. Armstrong later worked as an aerospace executive. He died at the age of 82.

input: Write a short biography of Neil Armstrong.
output: Neil Armstrong (1930-2012) was the first person to walk on the moon. A former Navy pilot, Armstrong served as a NASA astronaut from 1962 until his retirement in 1971. He was a member of the Gemini 8 crew and participated in the Apollo 11 mission, which landed on the moon on July 20, 1969. His first words after stepping onto the lunar surface were, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." Armstrong also served as deputy director of the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum before his death in 2012.

input: Write a short biography of Neil Armstrong.
output: Neil Armstrong (1930-2012) was an American astronaut and the first man to walk on the moon. Born in Ohio, he joined the Navy after college and later earned a master's degree in aerospace engineering. In 1962, he was selected as an astronaut for NASA. He became the Command Module pilot for the Gemini VIII mission and the Lunar Module Pilot for Apollo 11. On July 20, 1969, Armstrong landed on the moon and took the first steps by saying, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." Armstrong retired from NASA in 1971. He later taught at Purdue University.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian author and activist known for her novels and short stories exploring the experiences of Black women. Adichie grew up in Nigeria and studied communication and political science at Yale University. She published her first novel, Purple Hibiscus, in 2003. Her 2009 novel Half of a Yellow Sun won the Orange Prize for Fiction and was adapted into a film. She also wrote the non-fiction essay collection We Should All Be Feminists and the novels Americanah and Dear Ijeawele, or a Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions. Her TED Talks on feminism and the dangers of a single story have been viewed millions of times.

output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian writer and the author of several novels and short story collections. She has received numerous awards and honors for her writing, including a MacArthur Fellowship in 2008. Born in Nigeria, Adichie studied at Eastern Connecticut State University and Yale University, earning a degree in communication and a Ph.D. in creative writing. input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian novelist and activist. She is best known for her novel "Half of a Yellow Sun," set during the Biafran War. Adichie's other works include "Americanah" and "Purple Hibiscus." She has written for The New Yorker, The New York Times, and other publications, and she has taught creative writing at Princeton University. Adichie has won multiple awards for her work, including the Orange Prize for Fiction, the National Book Critics Circle Award, and the MacArthur Genius Grant. She is the author of "Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions," a collection of letters offering advice to parents on raising strong, independent girls. Adichie is also a public speaker and activist, speaking on topics such as feminism, race, and immigration. In 2019, Adichie delivered the TED Talk, "The Danger of a Single Story," which became a viral sensation. She has spoken on TEDx and TedWomen

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian author, essayist, and TED Talk speaker. Her books explore the experiences of women and people of color. Her novel _Americanah_ won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction and was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. Her other works include _Purple Hibiscus_ and _Dear Ijeawele, or a Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions_. Adichie was named by _Time_ magazine as one of the 100 most influential people in the world. She has also taught creative writing at several universities.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian-American novelist and short-story writer. Born in Nigeria, she moved to the United States as a child and received degrees from Harvard University and Yale University. She has written six novels and many short stories. Her best-known works include Purple Hibiscus, Americanah, and We Should All Be Feminists. Adichie's books often explore themes of gender, identity, and cultural history. She has won several awards, including the Commonwealth Writers Prize and a MacArthur "Genius Grant" Fellowship.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian-American writer and author. She began her career as a journalist before transitioning to writing novels and short stories. Adichie's debut novel "Purple Hibiscus" was critically acclaimed and translated into numerous languages. Her 2009 novel "Half of a Yellow Sun" won the Orange Prize for Fiction, while her 2013 novel "Americanah" won the US National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction. Adichie has also written for magazines such as The New Yorker and The New York Times. She is known for her unique perspective on identity, race, and feminism.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian writer and social justice advocate. Adichie was born in Nigeria and moved to the U.S. to study at Yale and Johns Hopkins. Her first novel, Purple Hibiscus (2003), won the Commonwealth Writers' Prize. Her later works, including Americanah (2013), address race and gender in a globalized world. Adichie speaks out against corruption and supports feminism, LGBT rights, and environmental causes. She has received numerous literary awards and appeared on the BBC's list of 100 most inspiring women in 2021.

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is a Nigerian novelist, essayist, and public speaker. She earned a BA from Yale University and an MFA from Eastern Connecticut State University. Adichie's first novel, "Purple Hibiscus," won the Commonwealth Writers' Prize for Best First Book. Her other works include "Half of a Yellow Sun," "Americanah," "We Should All Be Feminists," and "Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions." Adichie's novels and essays often explore the experiences of black women and gender inequality. She has also been an advocate for the #MeToo movement and critic of U.S. President Donald Trump. In 2019, she was honored with a MacArthur "Genius" Fellowship.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was the Prime Minister of India from 1966-1977 and 1980-1984. She was the first woman to serve as Prime Minister of India. Gandhi was born into India's political elite and joined the Congress Party at age 14. She served as Information and Broadcasting Minister under her father, Jawaharlal Nehru. She was Prime Minister from 1966 to 1977, and again from 1980 until her death in 1984. She expanded the powers of the prime minister and nationalized banks, insurance companies, and industries. Gandhi was criticized for her use of repressive policies to quell opposition and for her role in the 1984 Sikh riots.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was an Indian politician who served as Prime Minister of India from 1966-1977 and 1980-1984. She was the only woman to hold this position until 2004. Born into a prominent political family, Gandhi became involved in the Indian National Congress party and served in Parliament in the 1960s. After becoming Prime Minister in 1966, she oversaw the Green Revolution, which led to increased food production and helped India fight hunger. She also faced political instability and nationalist violence during her tenure, particularly during the Emergency (1975-1977). Gandhi was assassinated in 1984, and her son Rajiv Gandhi succeeded her as Prime Minister.

input: Write a short biography of Audre Lorde.
output: Audre Lorde (1934-1992) was an American writer, activist, and feminist. Born in Harlem, Lorde spent much of her childhood in the Caribbean and Jamaica. After returning to the United States, she joined the National Council of Negro Women and became active in the civil rights movement. Lorde co-founded Kitchen Table: Women of Color Press and edited "The Black Woman" anthology. Lorde published several collections of poetry and essays, including "Zami" and "A Burst of Light." She is remembered for her work on racial and sexual inequality and was an outspoken advocate for the LGBTQ community.
